choices.reason: Correct, VLSI stands for Very Large Scale Integration
Incorrect, this is not what VLSI stands for
Incorrect, this is not what VLSI stands for

questions.html: What is the difference between an ASIC and an FPGA?

choices.html: An ASIC is custom-built for a specific application, while an FPGA is a programmable device
choices.reason: Correct, an ASIC is Application-Specific Integrated Circuit, it is designed for a specific application, while an FPGA is a Field-Programmable Gate Array, it is a programmable device

choices.html: An ASIC is a programmable device, while an FPGA is custom-built for a specific application
choices.reason: Incorrect, this is the opposite of what ASIC and FPGA are

choices.html: There is no difference, ASIC and FPGA are interchangeable
choices.reason: Incorrect, ASIC and FPGA are different types of devices

choices.html: The difference in arrival times of the clock signal at different points in a circuit
choices.reason: Correct, clock skew is the difference in arrival times of the clock signal at different points in a circuit

choices.html: The amount of jitter in the clock signal
choices.reason: Incorrect, clock skew is not the same as clock jitter

choices.html: The delay introduced by the clock distribution network
choices.reason: Incorrect, this is not the definition of clock skew

choices.html: The difference between the clock frequency and the data rate
choices.reason: Incorrect, this is not related to clock skew
